items.title: [fyi] stubs for cachetools were submitted to typeshed
items.body:
Type stubs for this library were submitted to typeshed in https://github.com/python/typeshed/pull/4422

You don't need to take any action, but:
a) If you wish to include type stubs as part of your package, we're happy to transfer them to this repo (or potentially aid with the addition of inline types)
b) If you want us to remove the stubs from typeshed, we will!

items.title: Add optional Cython support?
items.body: After doing some testing it looks like using Cython at installation time can get significant performance savings without any code changes: * LRU: 34% faster * LFU: 6% faster * * RR: 20% faster * TTL * 0.25s: 41% faster * 1s: 41% faster * default: 39% faster * LFU boost is far smaller because `collections.Counter` is part of the standard library and is thus ignored by Cython. I tested using cProfile, with small variations of the following code: ```py import cachetools.func import random @cachetools.func.lru_cache(512) def my_function(a, b): return a % b for _ in range(1000000): my_function(random.randrange(100), random.randrange(1, 100)) ``` Doing this isn't that hard and can be made to be opt-in, so existing users wouldn't be impacted at all. Not even installation speed would change for them. Cython would be even more effective if we had PEP 484 type annotations it could use for guidance. I've seen in #160 that typing support was declined but maybe this would be a bit more of an incentive?

items.title: Don't use double underscores to simplify subclassing
items.body:
I'd like to create an MRU cache (see #114) and the simplest way to do this would be to inherit `LRUCache` and change `__update` to:

```py
def __update(self, key):
    self.__order.setdefault(key, None)
    self.__order.move_to_end(key, last=False)
```

The problem is, anything with a double underscore is private to the class due to [name mangling](https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/classes.html#private-variables). Thus, my subclass' `self.__order` is *not* the same as the superclass' one. I have to reimplement the entire thing from scratch, resulting in a lot of copy-pasted code.

An easy way to solve this problem would be to change all class-private identifiers (`__order`, `__update`, etc.) to use single underscores. This way, they still remain private (ish) to the class but still allow access to the subclasses.

items.title: TTLcache don't clear memory
items.body:
so i run this script to check memory usage of TTLcache:
```
from cachetools import TTLCache
import time
import psutil
cache = TTLCache(maxsize=5000, ttl=10)

print(psutil.virtual_memory())
print("started")
for i in range(5000):
    cache[i] = "AAAAAA" * 1000000
print(psutil.virtual_memory())
print("finished")
time.sleep(50)
print(psutil.virtual_memory())
```
And get thar output:
```
svmem(total=67457380352, available=56445067264, percent=16.3, used=9796333568, free=30661332992, active=15309488128, inactive=19676790784, buffers=284905472, cached=26714808320, shared=467402752)
started
svmem(total=67457380352, available=26374475776, percent=60.9, used=39866925056, free=590708736, active=45323694080, inactive=19676786688, buffers=284905472, cached=26714841088, shared=467402752)
finished
svmem(total=67457380352, available=26366201856, percent=60.9, used=39875198976, free=582213632, active=45330063360, inactive=19676934144, buffers=284913664, cached=26715054080, shared=467406848)
```
Does it means that TTLcache realy not clear memory after time said as TTL=N ends?
P.S. it realy works that i have no acess to elements after TTL, but memory still busy

items.title: [Feature] Would it be possible to add a file save for the cashe
items.body: Adding the ability to save the cashe to be used between file runs would help with reducing function runs even when a file crashes.

items.title: Improve popitem() exception context handling
items.body:
As pointed out by @cool-RR in #171, exceptions raised from `popitem()` are shown with more context information than expected:
```
>>> import cachetools
>>> d = cachetools.LRUCache(10)
>>> d.popitem()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/tkem/src/cachetools/cachetools/lru.py", line 29, in popitem
    key = next(iter(self.__order))
StopIteration

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/tkem/src/cachetools/cachetools/lru.py", line 31, in popitem
    raise KeyError('%s is empty' % self.__class__.__name__)
KeyError: 'LRUCache is empty'
```
In this case, the `StopIteration` exception is an implementation details of `LRUCache.popitem()` and should not be displayed. The same issue applies to the other cache types as well. IMHO, only the `KeyError` should be displayed, which is part of the `MutableMapping.popitem()` API.

items.title: documentation example doesn't work
items.body:
The cachetools documentation has an example of creating a custom function to allow dictionary arguments: <https://cachetools.readthedocs.io/en/stable/#module-cachetools.keys>. However, that example doesn't work for me:

====
```
# cat dict_test.py
from cachetools import *
from cachetools.keys import hashkey

def envkey(*args, env={}, **kwargs):
    key = hashkey(*args, **kwargs)
    key += tuple(sorted(env.items()))
    return key

@cached(LRUCache(maxsize=128), key=envkey)
def foo(x, y, z, env={}):
    pass

x = {}
x['abc'] = 1
x['def'] = 'def'
foo(1, 2, 3, x)
# python3 ./dict_test.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./dict_test.py", line 20, in <module>
    foo(1, 2, 3, x)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cachetools/decorators.py", line 19, in wrapper
    return cache[k]
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cachetools/lru.py", line 14, in __getitem__
    value = cache_getitem(self, key)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cachetools/cache.py", line 39, in __getitem__
    return self.__data[key]
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cachetools/keys.py", line 19, in __hash__
    self.__hashvalue = hashvalue = hash(self)
TypeError: unhashable type: 'dict'
```
====

I'm on Fedora 32 with python 3.8.2 and cachetools 4.1.0

items.title: Cache key hash's don't round trip via pickle
items.body:
I'm not sure if this is supported but answers on StackOverlfow indicate it is. When I use pickle to load a cache, the hash of the keys changes. It seems that `cachetools.keys._HashedTuple` doesn't round trip. The code below reproduces for me using Python 3.7.6 on Ubuntu Linux 18.04

You need to run this multiple times. Each time I run, the hash of the key for the same url changes. You can even comment out the call to `request` once you have a cached item. 

PS Just to be clear - this means that after pickle.load() all cache lookups for pickled (key,value) fail.

```
import cachetools
import pickle

try:
    with open("cache.pkl", 'rb') as f:
        cache = pickle.load(f)
except FileNotFoundError:
    cache = cachetools.TTLCache(maxsize=128, ttl=60*60)
    #cache = cachetools.LRUCache(maxsize=128)

def request(url):
    @cachetools.cached(cache)
    def _request(url):
        return None
    return _request(url)

url = 'https://api.darksky.net/forecast/XXX/-37.8136,144.9631,1546261200?units=si&exclude=currently,minutely,daily,alerts,flags'
response = request(url)  

keys = list(cache._Cache__data.keys())
if len(keys)>0:
    print(keys[0])
    print(type(keys[0]))
    print(hash(keys[0]))

with open("cache.pkl", 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(cache, f)
```

items.title: Add type hints
items.body:
Thanks for the very useful library!

Since the library no longer supports Python 2 and only supports Python 3.5+, it would be useful to add type annotations to functions and methods. This library is not so big, so it should not be difficult.

Code that uses the library will benefit from this change because type checking tools will better understand it.

See:
* https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/
* https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0561/
* http://mypy-lang.org

If you are positive about this idea, then I can create a PR.

items.title: [question] Thread safe?
items.body:
Are these cache implementations thread safe? Or am I better off acquiring a thread lock whenever I modify a cache?

I suppose it is a related question but what there be any interest in attempting to implement some sort of atomic compare-and-swap operation? I'm actually using the caches for small scale rate limiting and so it would be a useful feature which avoided the need for thread locks outside the cache.

items.title: pip install of cachetools installs 4.0.0 for Python 2
items.body:
We have an open source tool called [dsub](https://github.com/DataBiosphere/dsub), which still supports Python 2 in addition to Python 3.

When setting up `dsub` under Python 2, cachetools 4.0.0 now gets installed, but use of it fails with:

```
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/cachetools/__init__.py", line 3, in <module>
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/cachetools/cache.py", line 1, in <module>
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/cachetools/abc.py", line 1, in <module>
ImportError: cannot import name abstractmethod
```

It looks like it is possible to make PyPi aware of Python version requirements as described here:

https://packaging.python.org/guides/dropping-older-python-versions/

In the meantime, we have opened an [issue](https://github.com/DataBiosphere/dsub) for `dsub`, which describes a workaround and will likely pin to cachetools 3.1.1 for a while.

items.title: Cache type proposal
items.body:
Hello ! I have a cache idea with interesting use cases I think. I'm opening this issue to know if you would be interested in a PR with this kind of cache or if I should keep it in my app because you think this is too specific.

It's basically a "cache with fallback", with 2 caches internally, a TTL and a LRU.
- When there is no value in the TTL cache, you call the underlying function.
   - If the call returns a value, you save it in both caches.
   - If the call raises an error, you save in the TTL cache that you had an error
- If you have a value in the TTL cache, you return it
- If you have an error saved in the TTL cache, you return the value from the LRU cache if it exists, otherwise you raise the error

This behavior has notable properties :
- Your code will never call the underlying function more frequently than the ttl of the TTLCache
- If the underlying function returned a value once, you are guaranted to read at least that value (or a more recent one) in any call in the future
=> It's like a LRU cache with a "try to refresh if possible" if the value you want to read is too old
=> It's like a TTL cache with "fallback to last value" even if you cache miss because the last successful run of the underlying function is too old (and recent runs raised an error)

items.title: How to do ttl_cache + custom key ?
Partial caching - better caching control
items.body:
I think this may be similar, but possibly more generic to the exception handling issue (#138).  I'd really like a way of controlling the caching within the cached code.

The basic idea would be to have the current decorator immediately slurp the cache key and set a flag for that key which could be disabled within the cached code base.  At the end of the execution, the `cached` decorator would check to see if the flag is still set and then cache the results.  If the flag is not set, then it wouldn't cache the results.

And sort of a follow-on is that I'd like a way of ultimately resetting or dropping the cache based on an external to the cached code decision.  I suspect I could come up with a hack for that by simply re-initializing the cache, but I think I'd prefer it to be a method(s) on the cache itself.

items.title: Drop Python 2.7 support
items.body: Python 2 will reach end of life on Jan 1 2020. Although `cachetools` doesn't include much code for backward-compatibility, some small things may be cleaned up by dropping Python 2 support, e.g. setting `__wrapped__` on decorated functions explicitly.

items.title: Document how to use shared caches with @cachedmethod
items.body:
The `@cached` documentation already suggest how to use shared caches by including the function name (or whatever identifier) in the key. This is missing from the `@cachedmethod` docs.

See also  #132.

items.title: When two @cachedmethod()'s are called with the same arguments, results are comingled
items.body:
Hi! Thanks for this useful library 😃 

I encountered an unexpected behavior. I'm using `cachedmethod()` on several methods in the same class. My expectation is that these could all share a cache object, and would cache their results independently of each other. If two different cached methods were called with the same arguments, I'd expect a mechanism inside the decorator to determine that these are for different methods, and therefore should not share each others' results.

What I'm seeing instead is that if one cached methods is called, and then another is called with the same arguments, that the results of the first method are returned.

```py
class Cached(object):

    def __init__(self, cache, count=0, other_count=5):
        self.cache = cache
        self.count = count
        self.other_count = other_count

    @cachedmethod(operator.attrgetter('cache'))
    def get(self, value):
        count = self.count
        self.count += 1
        return count

    @cachedmethod(operator.attrgetter('cache'))
    def get_other(self, value):
        other_count = self.other_count
        self.other_count += 1
        return other_count
```

```py
    def test_that_methods_are_cached_independently(self):
        self.assertEqual(cached.get(0), 0)
        self.assertEqual(cached.get(0), 0)
        self.assertEqual(cached.get(1), 1)
        self.assertEqual(cached.get(1), 1)
        self.assertEqual(cached.get_other(0), 5)
        self.assertEqual(cached.get_other(0), 5)
        self.assertEqual(cached.get_other(1), 6)
        self.assertEqual(cached.get_other(1), 6)
        self.assertEqual(cached.get_other(2), 7)
        self.assertEqual(cached.get(2), 2)
```

It seems to me that this is a bug. Is that correct?

If so I'll open a PR with the failing test case, and see if I can fix it.

items.title: Mention that default cachetools.keys.hashkey prevents pickling of cache
items.body:
I guess a common use-case of `cachetools` is also to store the cache for future usages. This will surely often be done with the help of the `pickle` module. A strange problem arises when the default `key=cachetools.keys.hashkey` parameter is used. Since this function produces a `_HashedTuple` with a hash depending on **runtime**!

To reproduce, execute the following script:
```python
import pickle
from cachetools.keys import hashkey

my_key = hashkey( ('abc', 1) )
print("Hash of original key", hash(my_key))
with open('my_key.pickle', 'bw') as fh:
    pickle.dump(my_key, fh)
```
then execute **afterwards** the script:
```python
import pickle
from cachetools.keys import hashkey

my_key = hashkey( ('abc', 1) )
with open('my_key.pickle', 'br') as fh:
    my_orig_key = pickle.load(fh)

print("Hash of original key", hash(my_orig_key))
print("Hash of key that perfectly recreates the original key", hash(my_key))
```
The output of those scripts, ran one after another, will be like:
```
Hash of original key 5309672140285697764

Hash of original key 5309672140285697764
Hash of key that perfectly recreates the original key -3981844488918652932
```
Although anyone would expect that `('abc', 1)` leads to the same hash, this it isn't the case. In practise, that means that you might load your cache but you will not actually use the content of it but rather create "duplicate" entries. 

A simple workaround is to just not use `cachetools.keys.hashkey` but this should be mentioned in the docs or one could change the default implementation to not using `_HashedTuple`. Is this used for performance reasons btw? From the implementation is seems that it avoids the recalculation of the hash.

items.title: Compressed cache
items.body:
Is it possible to have a compressed cache? To start with something simple, how can I use `functools.lru_cache` with `gzip.compress` plus `gzip.decompress` all together? For convenience, assume the input and outputs to the target function are `bytes`. Can this be done with a custom decorator, and what would such a decorator look like? I should then similarly be able to use this with one of the preexisting `cachetools` decorators.

I consider this request important to save on memory while affording a bit of CPU expense. The size of the `bytes` object that I cache can be 50K to 500K of text multiplied by the cache size, making it worthy of compression.

Next, for `cachetools`, would it make sense to allow an optional `key_compression` and `value_compression` argument for each of its caches? Sometimes I need just the value compressed. If the key is stored in-memory, sometimes I also need it compressed. This would take in as an argument say the module object `gzip` or `zlib`, etc., so long as the object has the `compress` and `decompress` callables. For this to work in theory, what assumptions about the cached objects would have to be made? Any object can be held in memory, but only `bytes` objects can be compressed.

Sometimes I don't need even a compressed version of a 500K key to be stored in memory in a dict. In such cases, just a SHA2 hash as a key will suffice.

items.title: Consider time.monotonic if available
items.body:
[`time.monotonic`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/time.html#time.monotonic) is said to be available system-wide since Python 3.5. Why not use it as a default for `cachetools.TTLCache` and `@cachetools.func.ttl_cache` if it's available? As the docs for it say, "*The clock is not affected by system clock updates*". Using `time.time` as the default could sometimes lead to bugs.

When the `cachetools` package is imported, it could perhaps do something like this:

```python
try:
    DEFAULT_TTL_TIMER = time.monotonic
except AttributeError:
    DEFAULT_TTL_TIMER = time.time
```

items.title: TTLCache class\decorator LFU (and possibly other algorithms) support
items.body:
It's my understanding that TTLCache provides a max TTL for each value as well as protection against the max cache length and where cases that the cache length is about to overflow the max length a LRU function is used to choose the LRU value to remove from the cache... There are cases you might want to have a TTL Cache alongside LFU or other algorithms as the deciding algorithm for when the cache length is maxed.

My suggestion to add it is to allow setting the algorithm choice when declaring the TTLCache decorator\ initializing the class with LRU being the default value of said parameter.

items.title: Docs: Improve wording regarding thread safety
items.body: See #115: "Cache and its subclasses" may be misleading. "All the cache classes in this module" may be more clear.

items.title: Documenting the _Link class used in TTLCache
items.body:
Hi, would it be possible if there could be some documentation regarding the usage of the `_Link` class in TTLCache? The code is a bit convoluted to read due to the `__link` attribute referring to something different.

Will be happy to make a PR from suggestions.

items.title: Ttl cache does not protect itself from KeyError when entry doesn't exist during expire()
items.body:
Problem:

In multithreaded environments, there's a high chance that [`def expire(self, time=None)`](https://github.com/tkem/cachetools/blob/master/cachetools/ttl.py#L170) is called concurrently.
When that happens, there's a chance that `cache_delitem` (`Cache.__delitem__`) is called multiple times for the same element.
When that function is called multiple times, the operator ends up executing `del` over the cache Mapping which causes an undocumented `KeyError` on all but first call to clear the cache entry.

To reproduce:
1. Create a function with many calls. For example:

```
from threading import Thread
import cachetools
import random
@cachetools.cached(cachetools.TTLCache(maxsize=50, ttl=1))
def will_not_be_called_sometimes(value):
	import time
	time.sleep(value / 5)
random.seed(5)
def run():
	while True:
		will_not_be_called_sometimes(random.randrange(1, 30))
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
Thread(target=run).start()
run()
```

2. Run as much as needed until the exception starts to appear.

Note: In order to work, it might require running the program in a system with multiple CPU or CPU cores.

items.title: Support maxsize=None in cachetools.func decorators
items.body:
To more closely resemble `functools.lru_cache`, a `maxsize` argument of `None` should be supported.
This effectively disables any caching strategy and lets the cache grow without bounds.

items.title: Cache with csr_matrices
items.body:
I want to make a function cachable but, in the args of the function, I need to include a csr_matrix (dataframe vectorized through CountVectorizer model), but I know that csr_matrix are unhashable, and I dunno how to create a hashkey w/csr matrix. Anyone can help me?

Imagine the function (the original function is too large to give context :P): 

```
    @cached(cache)    
    def similarities_betw_text(id,vectorized_data):
        similarities=[]
        selected_id = vectorized_data[id]
        for row in vectorized_data:
              similarities.append(cosine_similarity(id,vectorized_data))
        return similarities
```

It gives: 

> TypeError: unhashable type: 'csr_matrix'

PD: I know that in the documentation appears the dict as unhashable, and solves it creating a key iterating over elements with a tuple:

```
    @cached(LRUCache(maxsize=128))
    def foo(x, y, z, env={}):
        pass
    
    def envkey(*args, env={}, **kwargs):
        key = hashkey(*args, **kwargs)
        key += tuple(sorted(env.items()))
        return key
```

items.title: Officially support Python 3.7
items.body: This should be supported by Travis by now.

items.title: Remove "missing" cache constructor parameter.
items.body: Deprecated since v2.1.

items.title: Add a cache_pop() method to compatible decorators
items.body: Please consider adding another method to all decorators called `cache_pop(*args, **kwargs)` that takes the same arguments as the wrapped function. This would enable a use case to clear a specific entry. This feature is not available in `functools.lru_cache` and would be a valuable extra feature in `cache tools`.

items.title: @cachedmethod: Remove 'self' from key arguments
items.body:
The whole point of the `cache` argument of `@cachedmethod` being a function is to select an appropriate cache for `self`. So there is little to no reason for passing `self` to the `key` function. This was simply an oversight when preparing for cachetools v2.0.0.

Main question is: is this merely an ordinary bug, or a breaking change which would have to wait until cachetools v3.0.0?

items.title: cache decorator causes issues with memory leak
items.body:
Hey tkem,

Consider the following naive example:

```
from cachetools.func import lfu_cache

class Foo(object):
    @lfu_cache(100)
    def bar(self):
        pass

foo = Foo()
foo.bar()
```

`foo` will not be properly garbage collected because it is still referenced as part of a key inside the cache.

```
import gc
gc.collect()
referrers = gc.get_referrers(foo)
assert 1 == len(referrers)
```

Is there a recommended approach to decorating a method? I can use `cachemethod` with a `key` function that excludes the instance inside the hash, but is there a preferred way?

Thank you,

PJ

items.title: TTL Deletion Hook
items.body: I need to hook into when a cache item is removed from a TTLCache. It seems that `expire()` doesn't call it's local `__delitem__()` or the `popitem()` methods when an item is removed via expiration. Are you interested in a pull request for this feature?

items.title: Error in envkey example
items.body:
The `dict` items in the `envkey` example need to be sorted to create a proper key:
```
def envkey(*args, env={}, **kwargs):
    key = hashkey(*args, **kwargs)
    key += tuple(sorted(env.items()))
    return key
```
It should also be mentioned that the cached function should not modify the `env` argument as a side effect.

items.title: caching with mutable arguments
items.body:
There are couple of reasons to implement that.

First, sometimes it just doesn't matter if function arguments are mutable or not.  For example, we may only care if the argument implements read-only sequence protocol, as tuple - function will work in same way for list.

Next, mutable arguments may be  used for efficiency reasons, even for mathematical functions.

Not sure, if there are no better alternatives, but probably pickle may be used to implement requested feature.  (And that "battery" is included to the stdlib.)
```
In [11]: def pickle_key(*args, **kwargs):
    ...:     return cachetools.keys.hashkey(pickle.dumps(args, 1) + pickle.dumps(kwargs, 1))
    ...: 
```
Serialization protocol looks to be a natural way to express a temporary "freeze" of the object structure.

items.title: Add "picklekey" hash key?
items.body:
Since quite a few questions address using the `cached` decorator with `list` or `dict` or other unhashable objects, it would be convenient to add a cache key that deals with unhashable argument types.
Instead of addressing each (common) unhashable type separately, maybe using `pickle.dumps()` to convert each and every argument into a string may be an option?
Since this will probably be a lot slower than the default `hashkey`, it should *not* be made the default, of course.

items.title: Documentation appears out of date
items.body:
Unless I'm doing something wrong?  Using the docs from here: http://cachetools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
```
import cachetools

@cachetools.func.ttl_cache(maxsize=1, ttl=5)
def test():
    pass

AttributeError: module 'cachetools' has no attribute 'func'
```

items.title: RRCache with default arguments cannot be pickled in Python 2.7
items.body:
Trying to pickle an `RRCache` with default `choice=random.choice` will result in an exception:
```
TypeError: can't pickle instancemethod objects
```
A workaround seems to be to use a custom `choice` function that forwards to `random.choice`, as already implemented in the unit tests.
It would probably be preferable to handle this to the `RRCache` implementation itself.

items.title: Overriding getsizeof() in a derived Cache class leads to an assertion
items.body:
```
>>> class C(Cache):
...   def getsizeof(self, value):
...     return value
... 
>>> c = C(2)
>>> c[1] = 1
>>> c[2] = 2
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/tkem/src/cachetools/cachetools/cache.py", line 59, in __setitem__
    self.__size[key] = size
  File "/home/tkem/src/cachetools/cachetools/cache.py", line 11, in __setitem__
    assert value == 1
AssertionError
```

items.title: Drop Python 3.3 support?
items.body: It seems to be a reasonable (and somewhat common) strategy to limit support to the last three Python 3 minor versions. Adhering to semver might become a hassle, though...

items.title: Support for decorating coroutines
items.body:
The memoization decorators could use support for coroutines:

```python
@cachetools.cached(cache={})
async def foo():
    pass
```

Currently this caches the coroutine itself, which can only be awaited once and will produce an error when awaited again.

items.title: Flask doesn't appear to unescape '+'
items.body:
I was trying to delete a collection with a space in the name: `@DATACENTERWashington 4`.
When I send it to `http://192.168.99.100:8081/v2/public/collections/%40DATACENTER_Washington+4?ORGID=16` it fails saying `Collection record not found for @DATACENTER_Washington+4`
When I send it to `http://192.168.99.100:8081/v2/public/collections/%40DATACENTER_Washington%204?ORGID=16` it succeeds. 
We need to support + as a replacement for space in a URL.

items.title: Split out cachetools.func into its own package
items.body: There are no dependencies, and this would help keeping cachetools "core" mean and lean.

items.title: Statistics on cache
items.body:
I would like to have statistics on cache, like `lru_cache.cache_info` and maybe more.

Before i start implementing anything, do you have any though on the subject ?
Should i add the behaviors directly on classes ? Under a flag condition ? Or maybe a mixin ? Or a dedicated object that would appear in the main API ?

items.title: Documentation: clear interest of Cache over a dict
items.body:
I came across [cachetools.cached](http://cachetools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#cachetools.cached) documentation, and it reads:

> The cache argument specifies a cache object to store previous function arguments and return values. Note that cache need not be an instance of the cache implementations provided by the cachetools module. cached() will work with any mutable mapping type, including plain dict and weakref.WeakValueDictionary.

So, what is the interest of a Cache object over a mutable mapping type like `dict` ?

All the explanations are given in Cache online documentation, but it seems that Cache has basically the same behavior as a `dict` in that particular case.

I think this should be made clear at this point (and maybe in the docstring of [Cache](https://github.com/tkem/cachetools/blob/master/cachetools/cache.py#L18) itself ?).

items.title: Support Python 3.6
items.body: Should be just an extra line in `travis.yml`...

items.title: Mistake in #cachetools.cached doc
items.body:
Hi,

in the [cachetools.cached](http://pythonhosted.org/cachetools/#cachetools.cached) is described how to use single cache for multiple functions, but there is small mistake in `import` statement. The line:
```python
from cachetools import cached, hashkey, LRUCache
```
have to be:
```python
from cachetools import cached, LRUCache
from cachetools.keys import hashkey
```
regards

items.title: I was expecting cachetools.lru_cache decorator
items.body: Where could I find it?

items.title: Improve documentation of replacement strategy
items.body:
"setitem() calls popitem() repeatedly" should probably be

  `Cache.__setitem__()` calls `self.getitem()` repeatedly

We are facing of the following issue:
`

KeyError: (6261778983944192L,)
`

We cache method which returns a long list of users:

@cachetools.cached(cachetools.TTLCache(maxsize=50, ttl=900)) # 900 seconds in cache

`

items.title: add argument for exclude invalid cache
KeyError TTLCache
items.body:
Hi, I received KeyError when I attributed the value to cache using TTLCACHE, for example:

I have this cache:

```python
WHITE_LIST_CACHE = TTLCache(maxsize=10000,
                            ttl=10)
```

And error ocurred now:

```python
WHITE_LIST_CACHE[project_id] = white_list
```

This traceback happens when he called self.expire and crash in del self.data[key] into cache_delitem method, he returned KeyError.

```python
def __setitem__(self, key, value, cache_setitem=Cache.__setitem__):
        with self.__timer as time:
            self.expire(time) <---------
            cache_setitem(self, key, value)
        try:
            link = self.__getlink(key)
        except KeyError:
            self.__links[key] = link = _Link(key)
````
--------------------------------------
```python
while curr is not root and curr.expire < time:
            cache_delitem(self, curr.key) <-----
            del links[curr.key]
            next = curr.next
            curr.unlink()
            curr = next
````
--------------------------------------
```python
    def __delitem__(self, key):
        size = self.__size.pop(key)
        del self.__data[key] <------ Exception happens here
        self.__currsize -= size
    def __contains__(self, key):
        return key in self.__data
```
Is this expected?

Thanks !

items.body:
Hi! tnx for cachetools. 
Can you please add some kind of internal view of current states of cache ?
i am talking about for example hit/miss, fullfilnes, min/max ttl in cache 
Our programmers use it heavy in latest code, so i'm as admin want to know how healthy our cache is.
Tnx!

items.title: cachetools in conda-forge
items.body:
I'm planning to add my package [vaex](https://github.com/maartenbreddels/vaex) to the conda-forge channel (see https://conda-forge.github.io), but I have cachetools as a dependency. Are you interested in adding it yourself? It's pretty easy, check out the instructions:
https://conda-forge.github.io/#add_recipe
Really nice package btw!

items.title: Move documentation to RTD
items.body: Uploading to PyPI seems to be no longer supported, at least using `upload_sphinx`...

items.title: Remove deprecated features
items.body:
- `@cachedmethod`:
  -  `typed` keyword argument
  - using a shared cached for multiple methods
  - wrapper function’s `cache` attribute
- `cachetools.func` decorators:
  - `getsizeof` and `lock` arguments
  - available from `cachetools` module

items.title: Move key functions to separate package
items.body: `cachetools.keys` might be a good choice, in case more functions are added later.

items.title: Support unlimited capacity
items.body:
In my opinion, unlimited cache capacity that called `maxsize` is useful when we use `TTLCache`.  This cache algorithm has own expiration condition above the size limit.  So it still works as "cache" even though it has no any size limit.  I want to control cache lifetime with only TTL not including the size.

I've already tried to make an unlimited `TTLCache` with `maxsize=float('inf')` and it looks good.  But it wasn't perfect because of `__repr__`:

``` python
>>> c = TTLCache(float('inf'), ttl=3)
>>> c['a'] = 123
>>> c.keys()
['a']
>>> c.keys()
[]
>>> c
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File ".../cachetools/ttl.py", line 142, in __repr__
    return cache_repr(self)
  File ".../cachetools/cache.py", line 35, in __repr__
    self.__currsize,
TypeError: %d format: a number is required, not float
```

@tkem, if you agree this about this idea, I'll make a merge request.

items.title: Weird wheel metadata.json
items.body:
See https://bitbucket.org/pypa/wheel/issues/164/space-separated-keywords-are-not-processed
My question: how did you build the wheel you upload to Pypi?
Which exact versions of pip/setuptools/wheel/distlib/Python do you use? and on which OS?

items.title: Remove unicode_literals from setup.py
items.body: At least this seems to mess up the `keywords`.

items.title: Update TTLCache documentation
items.body: Clarify when cache items are expired.

items.title: Add doctest to tox.ini
items.body: Need to refactor code samples wrt dict ordering first.

items.title: Do not call TTLCache.expire() from TTLCache.__delitem__()
items.body:
This should improve performance for methods which call `__delitem__` repeatedly, like `Cache.clear`.
An expired item should _really_ delete the item, though.

items.title: Use Counter.most_common() for LFUCache.popitem()
items.body: Apparently, this also works with negative counts, so _decrementing_ the count on item access may be the key here.

items.title: Drop Python 3.2 support
items.body: `pip` and `pytest` have done so, so why shouldn't we?

items.title: Reimplement LRUCache and TTLCache using OrderedDict
items.body: CPython 3.5 uses a C implementation, so there's no longer an excuse _not_ to use it.

items.title: Handle ValueError in Cache.__missing__()
items.body: Raised if `Cache.getsizeof(value)` is larger than `Cache.maxsize`. Should probably be ignored.

items.title: Expire cache items in TTLCache.currsize
items.body: Would allow getting rid of `Node.size`. Check side effects with `__repr__`, etc.

items.title: Fix use of Cache.__missing__ in TTLCache
items.body:
https://github.com/tkem/cachetools/blob/master/cachetools/ttl.py#L108

Also check other cache classes.

items.title: Update README for dist-packages
items.body:
Add something along the lines of "may be already available packaged for your Linux distribution".
Use Debian package as example.

items.title: Deprecate "missing" Cache constructor parameter
items.body:
Should be removed in v2.0 to allow for cleaner `Cache` implementation.
Deriving custom cache classes with a `__missing__` methods should work as expected, of course.

items.title: Add documentation on how to extend cache classes
items.body:
- override `popitem` to implement before/after callbacks when cached items are removed
- provide a `__missing__` method to implement special-purpose caches

items.title: Refactor Cache base class
items.body:
Follow-up to #51: 
- The `Cache` class should keep values and cached sizes in separate dicts, with the defaults case (size=1) requiring no overhead. 
- Possibility of deriving `Cache` from `dict` should be evaluated.
- Re-think generic `__repr__` implementation based on `Cache.__data`.
- Clean up cache implementations.

items.title: Document pending removal of deprecated features
items.body: Add a note that deprecated features will be removed in v2.0, and that clients still using these should specify their dependencies accordingly, e.g. `cachetools ~= 1.1`.

items.title: Update README/introduction docs
items.body: `cachetools` now features much more than cache classes, so the introduction `pycon` samples should also show use of the decorators and maybe custom keys.
